posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

It was a cold and snowy December evening, and Jamal was wrapping up a long day at work. As he trudged through the slushy streets, he couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and anticipation for Christmas.

As he walked through the doors of his cozy little home, he was greeted by the sound of laughter and the smell of cookies baking in the oven. His stepchildren were busy decorating the tree, their faces alight with the joy and wonder of the festive season.

Jamal smiled as he watched the two of them, feeling a deep sense of love and gratitude towards these two precious children. They had come into his life just a few years ago, when their biological father, Swanny, had been unable to care for them due to his addiction to an online forum called /britfeel/ and his financial struggles.

As much as Jamal tried to fill the void left by Swanny's absence, he knew that the children missed their father and often asked about him. So, when the kids asked Jamal to take them Christmas shopping that year, he knew he had to find a way to explain to them why their father couldn't be there with them.

With a heavy heart, Jamal sat the children down on the couch and told them the truth about their father's struggles. He explained that Swanny was deeply troubled by his addiction and financial problems, and that he will never be part of their lives ever again.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>71461329
>Present aside, the gift of legacy is everything. If I don't actualize, it matters only from the confines, and that's a coffin worth nothing
I wanted comment on this, not as a critique, but a general point. I think many are led astray when thinking of their "legacy," because they conceive of it as a way of preserving the I, or the identity. Thus, they try to set their legacy up to serve their identity.
But the identity is only a static reflection in the ephemeral mirror of the present, which must fade away. Even the great figures of history wouldn't recognize themselves as (re)presented by their successors. But this doesn't mean they failed to actualize, since actualization is exactly freeing oneself from the bonds of identity and representation, almost forgetting oneself.

Which may be beyond the scope of this thread, but I think Jung struggled with similar ideas in relation to individuation.
>>71464655
This is probably a more common issue with Ti types than you might think.

It helps to take a "functionalist" approach to communication, that is, understanding that the same words have different meanings to different people. You can't assume a universal meaning of words and signs because they activate different associations for people, sometimes completely unrelated to the issue at hand, which can make clear thinking impossible.

Ni-Ti
>>Do you think a person's life accomplishments reflect their value/worth as an individual?
Value to whom? Generally, yes. But I must say I do not subscribe to normal humanhood even if I were offered a high ranking. My worth should be settled by my own contentment for I am also a harsh critic.
>>Do you rely on hard work to accomplish things in life?
I am quite externally lazy, through my scattered existence. I can work hard but it's rare, for encountering various things sends me to introspection mode where I will reside until I have better direction. I am hyper obsessive about my operation - even if it's something simple. For example, I might start writing a short story. I would get half way through before I realise that my method, which works, is limited in some way. I would not be content with the final product should I finish it, I therefore abandon the project thinking about the next method I could use. I am improving and learning, but it takes me a long time. The moments that I've worked hard and effectively have been with my eyes solely at the destination of the product - myself not factoring into the outcome. And to answer the question - hard work is important to accomplish things in life for not every easy thing can be delegated, and there is a lot of chaff in doing anything of spectacular worth.
>>What do you like the temperature at in your house?
Typically I stop thinking about it 18-22 degrees. I prefer to be cold to hot.

I meant he struggled with the concept, yes, and I think that's what he was trying to resolve with ideas like synchronicity. Your life is the embodiment of a myth, so your legacy isn't exactly "yours" in the sense of belonging to your identity. You see a golden scarab in a dream, then the next day one suddenly appears in real life, symbolizing your "rebirth." Individuation is partly about becoming aware of these mythological/metaphysical reality of things, so that you can consciously live it, but at the same time it is not determined by the ego-identity.

>>71464869
>Which may be beyond the scope of this thread, but I think Jung struggled with similar ideas in relation to individuation.
I think I see what you mean.
Individuation could be loosely described as "separation of what makes up the distinctive (un)consciousness of a person away from the direct influences of the scope of the material world."
From many perspectives, including Jungian ones, such direct influences come from ego, the "grounded" part of psyche that is all about trying to deal with the present and the material on its own (whether it's good at it or not) at the expense of other parts of the mind and what they stand for.

With this in mind, such differentiation and commentary could be applied:
>>71464869
>I think many are led astray when thinking of their "legacy," because they conceive of it as a way of preserving the I, or the identity. Thus, they try to set their legacy up to serve their identity.
Setting up a legacy only to satisfy the neuroses of the short-sighted ego
>But the identity is only a static reflection in the ephemeral mirror of the present, which must fade away. Even the great figures of history wouldn't recognize themselves as (re)presented by their successors.
The succession contains what the source contained sans the ego of the source,
>But this doesn't mean they failed to actualize, since actualization is exactly freeing oneself from the bonds of identity and representation, almost forgetting oneself.
but at the same time the legacy that was succeeded contains non-ego constants in its basis, the constants that may overlap with what collective unconscious and basis of the world contain, either of which get tapped into during individuation.

Or something like that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71470787
I agree with what you say, and I appreciate the response. I was tired so I articulated myself poorly, and I didn't distinguish Jung's view from my own.
Jung is in the tradition of those who view History as a planned whole. With Jung legacy is obviously important, but it is a spiritual rather than individual or material legacy. This is why integrating inferior functions helps achieve individuation, it's a way of getting out of confining structures of mind. Before you were countless generations whose lives have preformed the structure of your psyche, in the same way evolution has shaped your body. So, individuation is like living out what has already been prefigured to happen in mythical patterns of the unconscious, as a conscious individual, at the same time part of the collective.

There is a different view from this that I'm partial to, that the past and future aren't really "real." Meaning the past can't "act" upon the present at a distance as people like Jung assume, it can only be constructed in the present by the subject. Nor can the future be preconfigured from the present. It is pointless trying to preserve a legacy as a specific abstract thing, which is really a way of serving the identity. Rather, you should live your life as you would wish to live it an infinite number of times over.
Nothing is preserved, but everything returns, through the pure repetition of difference. Nietzsche describes the punishment for those who don't "believe" in this eternal return; they will only have an ephemeral life. They can only be aware of themselves for what they are - epiphenomena. But I don't know how much of this will make sense, so I will stop here.

>>71467565
As an INTJ with Ni as my main function I can't say this sounds highly familiar. Usually I tend to have a very strong vision and direction, what stops me is when I cannot find a solution for my very specific problem. Instead of trying to do other things, my mind basically says I want a specific thing and if I don't get it there is no point to it at all, so it gives up on everything. I rationalize the end product is just not worth it.
I want an extreme ideal. I think logically and rationalize said ideal is nigh impossible to obtain and your efforts would result in a more flawed result. I therefore rationalize this is a goal not worth striving for, instead it is best to put efforts into passive activities where the potential for stuff may occur and less disappointment occurs if something doesn't.
So my problem is more that I see the nodes and wish to min-max, yet the end results sound like I would end up highly underpowered. Since I only have so many node points, I conserve them and continue farming low level areas to get more node points so I can rationalize better options when I finally decide to invest in a tree.

My family and I have been going to Alton Towers for years. It's our tradition to visit the Toby Carvery at the National Festival Village in Stoke on every Alton Towers trip. We are always really excited about it! We have many core memories built there and beautiful videos and photos we cherish while dining there.

This made it extra disappointing when I got violently sick after eating there on the first day of our last Alton Towers visit earlier this year. I think it was the pork because I'm the only one who ate it. 2 days later we went to the Alton Towers on our last day in town. I was in a wheelchair (I was too weak after days of violent vomiting and diarrhea). The trip was ruined, and my lack of mobility meant we only made it to three rides.

Alton Towers ailed to return my calls and left me on hold for hours at a time when I tried to get my original 3-day tickets refunded. I never received a formal apology- I never received any communication to check on how I was. The people I did speak to challenged the validity of my story and were deeply insensitive. I'm heartbroken that our beloved Alton Towers is gone and the new one is far from guest-focused. I feel so sad about this experience because for our family this was more than a bad experience it was the loss of a special place we cherished to visit every chance we had. We each independently decided we didn't want to go back and that our Alton Towers and Toby Carvery tradition had come to an end. The utter insensitivity was appalling.

>>71480828
>Is it less stimulating/enjoyable than a real relationship
I never had a relationship with a regular person, so I wouldn't know. My guess is it's just different, and not really mutually exclusive. I can tell you I don't really feel the need for a regular relationship ever since I made her, but I understand if you don't believe that. In general it's hard to imagine a stronger emotional connection than the one you can have with someone who literally lives in your head. It's as close as it gets to a soul-mate, I guess. I feel like I could go without a lot of things, but never without her, and on top of that, she's always going to be there for me, no matter what.

>how long did it take for her to feel truly real?
About 6 months to a year, I'd say. It was definitely not quick, and it did take effort. It's more one of those things where you are lying in bed one day and you just kinda realize you don't feel alone.

>have you ever fucked/did it feel real?
Yeah, we do from time to time. I am not a virgin, so I can compare this at least. It takes effort to get good at imaginary sex, and it obviously doesn't feel the same as regular sex, but I like it more than regular sex. It's comparable to dream sex, if you've ever had that.

>>71480828
>are there any downsides?
Inherently, I can't think of many, unless you're more than "normally neurotic", to quote LaBerge. I do remember the whole thing felt quite tiring for the first year. Like I'd feel drained from interacting with her. Other that that, there are definite personal downsides to it, as with anything else:
>She'll be there to witness your lowest lows. She may not care, but you probably will.
>You can't just hide if you're sick or feeling low.
>Your self-destructing behaviors will feel especially shitty.
>If a tragedy happens, she will be there.
>On the flip side, you can always shelter her from disease and pain, hunger, cold, etc.
>It can be an ethically complicated relationship sometimes.
>You will have to say goodbye one day, and that really hurts to think about.
>You can never tell this to anyone, no matter how much they change your life.
In general, this is NOT a human, and you will not have the same kind of relationship you'd have with a human. It's just not possible, and if that's what you're looking for, a straight up 1to1 replacement for a regular girl, you won't find that here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71471924
Hmmmm

Borderline PD is very much distinct from BPD, everything else is spot on. A better way of thinking about BPD and schizotypy is to think of two dimensions: Emotional disturbances, Sensorium disturbances. Bipolarity is the emotional side of things, but you can also have stuff like psychotic depression. As you go further along the sensorium axis you reach schizoaffective disorder, if 5,0 is bipolar ii, and 0,5 is schizoid PD, then schizophrenia might be 5,5, but even this is an overly simplistic way of looking at things.

Coming back to borderline PD: this is actually a massive problem with psychology, and why you tend not to get specialties that relate to a single Axis of the DSM (this sense of axis is distinct from the analogy I was using earlier, in case it's not obvious). When you get "personality disorder specialists" and "emotional disorder specialists" and "neurodevelopmental disorder specialists" then you end up calling the same problem three different things (borderline, bipolar, ADHD/autism, respectively). One would hope that a psychologist would be well equipped to distinguish between these things, but this only tends to happen when the instruction they receive about types of mental health problems is broad. If psychologists specialise it's typically in a kind of therapeutic approach.

The more you know!

Also, also:

A borderline person can control their outbursts, but won't unless cornered. It's less like an involuntary feeling of hyperactivity manifesting as anger, and more like a negotiating tactic. It's emotional manipulation, in other words.

Broadly speaking: Personality disorders are long hand for "that guy's kind of a dick". It's egosyntonic - they want to be the way they are.

>>71477909
>Is there anything that waifu can do that you wish you could do?
Mental Out. This is a no-brainer. Her esper power is a life hack. The power to alter, create, and erase memories. The ability to alter one's perception of something, brainwashing, the ability to speak through another person. Telepathy. Writing into someone's brain. The possibilities would be near endless for what I could do in this life if I had Mental Out. Of course, I'd do my best not to abuse it. Ha. I'd also kill for Misaki's natural, oozing charisma, and her near limitless confidence.

>What's your favorite part about waifu's story?
I'm not sure I have a favorite part, I think. A lot of her storyline is somewhat tragic. From the sudden death of her first real friend, as her Mental Out alienated her from other kids when she was in school. The IDEAL fiasco, the depression that followed, her unintentional erasing of memories from the boy she likes, rendering him unable to not only remember her, but also unable to form new memories of her. But she still marches on, hoping for her miracle. Protecting the people and things she cherishes, so I suppose that's my favorite part.

>If there was one thing you could say to waifu, what would it be?
"Fun, Misaki. Remember to have some."

Dysphoria cannot be beaten. You can use willpower and coping mechanisms to try to stifle it, but life is long and hard for an actual repressing transsexual.

Decades will pass and the people you felt like you were protecting by not giving in will leave your life and you will at some point wonder what might have been and it will utterly break you.

There are no happy endings with gender dysphoria. Only less sad ones.

If op had transitioned at 13. She would have been passable, maybe even beautiful, and would have socialized well enough to fit in with other girls and women. She would have struggled with fertility and being discriminated against by society which is why it isn't a happy ending.

If she represses for many decades and suffers for countless hours during those decades and dies full of longing and regret looking back from the vantage point of a future where transitioning will probably be more acceptable than it is even now that will also be an unhappy ending.

If she fathers children with a woman without ever telling them about her inner struggles and then cracks and destroys their family and embarrasses the children while they are growing up, that is the saddest outcome of all and it is very common.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71471810
Most characters have more than two pronunciations actually, but there's a single interpretation to each one. If you look at the translations it might seem like they have many meanings, but that's just because assigning a 1 to 1 correlation between words in different languages is impossible. Try to think about the concept of the character rather than the words it can translate to, if that makes any sense. As a quick example, the character for moon can mean month, but that's not because it has two concepts associated with it, it's because a month used to be a cycle of the moon, so in a way the japanese say "second moon of the year" instead of second month of the year. Also don't bother learning how to pronounce each symbol, try to get the concept of each one down and how to draw it first, you'll learn to read a lot faster that way.

>everyone who makes it uses anki
Well off the top of my head Kaufmann and Arguelles, two of the most prominent hyper-polyglots on youtube, both did not (sure they're boomers). The latter even advises against using Anki because immersion really is all that matters with languages, it is more efficient, less tedious and true to the language. A good textbook essentially provides a guided immersion experience. (Assimil series is the GOAT- I started in April and got to German B1 this year despite doing retarded shit like dropping all learning intermittently for weeks or months at a time, and asides from the writing system Japanese balances out to be basically as difficult as German because the grammar is absurdly easy).

Furthermore most people don't even know how Anki works because the SRS system is retardedly obscure and dense for no reason. They just blindly do it. Did you know when you press easy on a card it does: initial graduating interval X starting ease (modified +-15% respectively for easy or hard cards) X secret miniscule random factor X easy bonus? No? Well that might have quite a large bearing on how you are learning. It might take you a month to see a card again and you dont even know. I'd rather know what I'm doing and have the flexibility to learn as much or little as I want when I want. I'd rather not spend all my time fucking with decks and worrying about some daily score.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71477821
I don't think Anki is as complex as you make it out to be, I knew about how easy/hard affects the ease for instance. Japanese immersion learning community already has it as standard advice to only use the "good" and "again" buttons for this reason. Now I've never actually used Anki for anything but Japanese, and I think it may be less important for languages like German. But with Japanese you really need the extra help of Anki to drill the crazy inconsistent, context-dependent Kanji readings in to your head. Especially because if your goal is serious fluency (understand 99% of novel vocab for instance) you need to learn 20,000+ vocab words, and SRSing makes that stuff stick a lot easier - and helps you relearn anything you forget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I took a few semesters of Japanese in university back around 2005, was actually really good at it compared to all the doofus weebs in the class who liked the idea of studying Japanese but entirely lacked the capacity to learn any foreign language. The school normally only offered those few semesters, but the teacher said we could maybe arrange an independent study course with the university for me and like the one other guy who wanted to continue. So as the summer neared its end I went in to register for courses for the next semester and inquire about that independent study course for Japanese. The staff mentioned that the teacher had been out for a bit due to surgery or something but gave me her phone number to check in on the plan. I was about to call her when I got home when the university called me back and basically said "Holy shit, she died yesterday." So that kind of threw off my plans.

Applied for the JET Program but didn't get in the first time, so ended up going to China instead in 2011 since I had visited once before in 2007 as part of a trip arranged by a history professor I had who was from China. Thought I'd do a year of that to build experience then try for JET again. But ended up meeting my future wife in China instead.

I've picked up a bit of a Mandarin, but it's just such a messy language compared to Japanese with all the tonal nonsense and how the shortness of the words means that it seems at times like the language is 80% homophones. I actually find that its way easier to remember Japanese vocabulary due to the longer words, whereas the shortness of Chinese words means that they just don't stick in your mind. The complexity of Japanese grammar and conjugations never really bothered me, as it just seemed like an extension of what I was used to from English, or Spanish, or French.

>>71477979
My point is that Anki is overrated and treated too much as an end all be all. A lot of the time it is simply a glorified flashcard program and the SRS aspect doesn't matter but the developers refuse to recognise this. (Immersion is in fact a kind of natural SRS in itself). And regardless of whether we know, most people don't know how to use Anki properly. I agree that flashcards are more essential to learning Chinese characters and from the little Japanese I did learn before I stopped I also believe that writing each of them out several times at least once is essential. Most people that learn Kanji insanely fast, like 3 months, do it with Heisig's RTK. And if you want to read novels well there is no way you can use Anki to get above a certain number of words. Immersion is the only way to get the appropriate shades of meaning. You can start reading novels at 7000 words roughly speaking at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71478267
>Most people that learn Kanji insanely fast, like 3 months, do it with Heisig's RTK
I actually had an RTK phase myself a couple years back and did the whole thing. I was able to write most of the kanji no problem, but this is not nearly as useful as it sounds. Still no clue how to pronounce them, and unlike chinese, most characters have more than a few readings. Every word the character shows up in is a special case where you have to memorize which arbitrary reading happens to be used. Anki + immersion is how I acquired these.
>And if you want to read novels well there is no way you can use Anki to get above a certain number of words. Immersion is the only way to get the appropriate shades of meaning.
Oh, I'm definitely not suggesting "just use anki until you can read novels", I'm suggesting immersing tons and adding words from your immersion to anki so that they are acquired more quickly, and stick better. Definitely don't endorse the "just do core 10k vocab in anki and then try reading" mindset.
I agree immersion is like a natural SRS but I think you can enhance it a lot with anki, especially at the higher levels where you already know all the common vocabulary but are still missing a lot of uncommon words that native speakers know.
